title-group.article-title: Application of GIS/AHP in siting sanitary landfill: a case study in Northern Cyprus

contrib-group.aff: Eastern Mediterranean University, Famagusta, North Cyprus via Mersin 10, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Can Kara, Eastern Mediterranean University, Famagusta, North Cyprus via Mersin 10, Turkey Email: c_kara77@yahoo.com

abstract.p: The present study utilized a multi-criteria evaluation (MCE) method in a geographical information systems (GIS) environment to evaluate the suitability of potential landfill sites in Northern Cyprus. To determine the most suitable landfill site, one of the MCE techniques, called analytical hierarchy process (AHP), was combined with a GIS to examine 12 criteria: distance from waste generation centres; distance from roads; slope; distance from surface waters; distance from groundwater areas; distance from environmentally sensitive areas; vegetation types; soil productivity; soil permeability; distance from settlements; distance from cultural sites; distance from stone quarries. The relative importance weights of these criteria were estimated using AHP and criteria maps were developed by using GIS spatial analysis. At the final stage two different suitability maps were produced using two different groups of weights. The first group suitability map had 11 052 (ha) with high suitability class, whereas the high suitability areas decreased to 5982 (ha) in the second group. Moreover, the seven potential sites identified within the first group decreased to four in the second suitability map. However, potential sites such as Gungor, Degirmenlik, Kirklar and Cayonu had similarities with higher suitability values and these same locations were regarded as suitable according to the both first and second suitability map results.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The present study investigated a multi-criteria evaluation (MCE) method in a geographical information systems environment to evaluate the suitability of various locations for use as a landfill site in Northern Cyprus. To determine the most suitable location, one of the MCE techniques, called analytical hierarchy process (AHP) was combined with a GIS to examine the systematically determined criteria.

The selection of the main siting criteria obviously targets financial efficiency and minimization of environmental damage to natural resources and public health. In general, economic environmental and social criteria are required on the first phase of evaluation. Economic criteria (distance to roads, slope, etc.) must be considered in the siting of landfills; these include the costs in relation to the development and operation of the site (Erkut and Moran, 1991) Environmental criteria (distance to surface waters, ground waters, etc) is also very important as the landfill may affect the ecology of the vicinity (Kontos et al., 2003) Furthermore, social/physical criteria (distance to residential areas, tourism destinations, etc), should be considered as important factors as the ‘Not in my backyard’ (NIMBY) or ‘Not in anyone’s backyard’ (NIABY) phenomena create tremendous pressure on the decision-makers dealing with landfill site selection (LSS).

Establishing the criteria sets given above require comprehensive spatial information databases for the evaluation process. Various spatial information layers such as settlements, road networks, slope, water resources, and soil characteristics are used for site selection via successive spatial operations. Buffering, overlaying, updating and joining are those most commonly used to organize spatial data within the process.

Geographical information systems (GIS) have emerged as useful computer-based tools for spatial operations such as entering, storing, manipulating, analysing and displaying geo-referenced data (Lukashes and Warith, 2001). Due to their ability to manage large volumes of spatial information from various resources, GIS are ideal for site selection studies (Kao et al., 1997). They have been widely applied in the past for site selection studies (Curtis and Hardin Perry, 2000; Haaren and Fthenakis, 2011; Nikolakaki, 2003; Thomas, 2002; Woodhouse et al., 2000).

In addition to the GIS applications, MCE methods have to be integrated to achieve an optimal result through the site selection process. These methods can be evaluated as a major tool to assist decision-makers, by dividing the decision problems into smaller understandable parts, analysing each part separately and then integrating the parts in a logical manner.

The integration of both GIS and MCE techniques improves decision-making because it establishes an environment for transformation and combination of geographical data and stakeholders preferences (Malczewski, 1999). GIS provide efficient manipulation and presentation of the data and MCE supplies consistent ranking of the potential landfill areas based on a variety of criteria (Sener et al., 2006). MCE consists of a series of techniques that permit a range of criteria relating to particular issues to be scored weighted and then ranked by experts or stakeholders (Higgs, 2006).

Among the MCE techniques, AHP has been widely used in LSS in recent years. Pokhrel and Viraraghavan (2005) carried out an evaluation of solid waste management concerning the siting of landfills in Nepal. Padmaja et al. (2006) identified a solid waste disposal site in Hyderabad city using AHP and GIS. Al-Jarrah & Abu-Qdais (2006) focused on the problem of siting a new landfill using an intelligent system based on fuzzy inference. Sumathi et al. (2008) used an optimized land use site selection based on MCE analysis and GIS-based overlay analysis for the detection of the most suitable landfill site in Pondicherry, India. Moeinaddini et al. (2010) presented a study using a process called spatial multi-criteria evaluation (SMCE) that combines GIS and MCE methods to evaluate the suitability of sites in Karaj. Guiqin et al. (2009) utilized spatial information technologies and AHP for LSS in Beijing, China. Thus, the main aim of the present study was to determine the most suitable landfill sites for the Northern Cyprus region by using GIS with AHP methods.

sec.title: Study area
sec.p: Cyprus lies about 40 miles (65 km) south of Turkey and is located in the north-eastern part of the Mediterranean region (Figure 1). It has an area of 9453 km2 and Northern Cyprus covers approximately 35% (3355 km2) of the whole island. It has a population of 294 906 according to the 2011 Turkish Cypriot Community (TCC) census data.

Similar to many other countries, Northern Cyprus also faces a wide range of economic, social and environmental issues and problems. The critical environmental issues that need to be addressed cover not only waste management but also water supply, wastewater treatment and environmental protection. Waste collection and disposal in particular is inadequate and does not meet European Union (EU) technical standards. The level of awareness about environmental issues is also poor at both community and administrative levels.

In Northern Cyprus, there are 164 settlements (cities and villages) and 28 municipalities. These municipalities collect the waste for 117 settlements and operate 23 dumping yards (open dumps) (Figure 2). These open dumps are the cause of several environmental problems and health risks (Ruben and Paralik, 2006).

caption.p: Existing dumps sites and in the study area (Source: Ruben and Paralik, 2006).

sec.p: According to the Master Plan on Solid Waste Management (MPSWM, 2008) in TCC, the average generation of municipal waste (including both household and commercial waste) in Northern Cyprus is about 400 kg capita−1 year−1. Based on 1.4% average annual population growth and 3.2% gross domestic product growth rates, the amount of solid waste that would be accumulated in 25 years was projected as 1 836 641 tonnes. Moreover, the area required for the central landfill site was calculated approximately as 190 000 m2 (19 ha) for the next 25 years (2008 to 2033) in the study area. The MPSWM emphasized that more than one landfill site for Northern Cyprus would not be cost-effective. Consequently, a single LSS within the study area was investigated.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: The criteria set and hierarchy structure for the case area was determined in the first stage. In the second stage, GIS database development related to the case area was completed. In the final stage, the analysis and evaluation were performed. These steps and a flowchart of the methodology for landfill siting is depicted in Figure 3.

In order to start the identification process of potential sites, a list of the most relevant criteria was selected through literature review from different studies based on GIS and AHP (Akbari, 2008; Ghose et al., 2006; Guiqin et al., 2009; Kontos et al., 2003, 2005; Moeinaddini et al., 2010; Nas et al., 2008; Sener et al., 2010; Sharifi et al., 2009; Sumathi et al., 2008; Yesilnacar and Cetin 2005). These criteria reflect the basic economic, natural and physical policies defining the suitability of a site for development of waste management infrastructure facilities (Figure 4).

caption.p: A list of most relevant criteria set for evaluation and hierarchy model of LSS.

sec.p: As given above, LSS requires the consideration of a comprehensive set of factors and balancing of multiple objectives when determining the suitability of a particular area. It involves a complex array of critical factors that are derived from economic policies and environmental disciplines. Accordingly, for LSS, MCE techniques are required. These techniques were developed to evaluate alternatives based on the decision-maker’s subjective values and priorities. It is a decision-aid and a mathematical tool allowing the comparison of different alternatives or scenarios according to many criteria.

AHP was developed by Saaty (1980) to help the decision-makers to arrive at the best decision in a case of multiple conflicting objectives (criteria). It is a flexible decision-making tool for multi-criteria problems and was used in this study to determine the relative importance of LSS criteria. In order to do that, a complex problem is divided into a number of simpler problems within the hierarchy (Guiqin et al., 2009).

The hierarchical structure of the decision-making problem was established by using AHP for the case study and it consists of three levels (Figure 4). The first level represents the main goal of the decision hierarchy which is the LSS, the second level represents the three main criteria, which emphasize financial restriction, environmental protection and physical protection, respectively, and the third level includes twelve criteria for different aspects of the main criteria.

Based upon the requirements for landfill siting, relative importance weights for the various criteria were calculated using a pair-wise comparison method. The pair-wise comparisons of various criteria were organized into a square matrix. To rate each pair-wise comparison and to fill in the matrix cells, the relative importance of the row variable to its corresponding column variable was considered within comparison process. These values were obtained based on the nine-point rating system described by Saaty (1980) (Table 1).

caption.p: Pair-wise comparison values for analytical hierarchy process (AHP).

sec.p: The principal eigenvalue and the corresponding normalized right eigenvector of the comparison matrix gave the relative importance of the criteria being compared. The elements of the normalized eigenvector were weighted with respect to the criteria or sub-criteria and rated with respect to the alternatives (Bhushan and Rai, 2004). The consistency of the matrix was then evaluated. If this consistency index failed to reach a threshold level, then the answers to the comparisons were re-examined. where λmax is the greatest eigenvalue of preference matrix; and n is the order of the matrix.

The CI can be compared to that of a random matrix, RI, such that the ratio, CI/RI, is the consistency ratio. Consistency ratios (CR) were calculated to verify the coherence of the judgments, their values must be less than 0.10 to be acceptable.

After checking the reliability of the pairwise comparisons, the simple additive weighting method (SAW) was used to prepare a suitability map for the landfill. A total score was obtained for each alternative by multiplying the importance weight assigned for each attribute by the scaled value given to the alternative on that attribute, and summing the outcomes of all attributes. With a SAW, the criteria sets were combined by applying a weight to each, followed by a summation of the results in the suitability map (Eastman, 2001) (Equation (2)).

sec.title: Criteria description
sec.p: The evaluation criteria used in this paper were classified into three groups, namely the economic, natural and physical criteria. The available information related to these criteria sets such as road network, geology, soil types, etc. was collected from different resources and produced in a digital format. The required data layer and spatial attributes were generated by creating digital layers or updating existing ones with spatial operations. To perform spatial operations, well known GIS software package ArcGIS Desktop (ArcInfo 9.3) and spatial analysis tools were used in order to create digital criteria layers and their databases.

These databases mainly include the zones which present the sub-criterion. For each criteria layer, the main policies for the evaluation, the determination of exclusionary zones and sub-criterion zones are given in Table 2. These zones were converted into a grid map 30 m × 30 m cell-sized resolution maps (Figure 5(a–l)) and each zone was weighted by AHP for spatial weighting analysis.

tr.td: Landfill sites should be located on the areas close to center of most populated urban centers, in terms of amount of waste. (MPSWM 2008)
Existing roads should be used to avoid the high cost of constructing connection roads (Nas et al., 2008; Vasiloglu, 2004).
Landfill sites should not be seen from highways for aesthetical reasons (Ghose et al., 2006; Sharifi et al., 2009).
Landfill sites should be located on the areas with medium altitude surrounded by hills and with less than 20% slope (Akbari, 2008).
Landfill sites should be located on areas that are remote from surface water resources (Guiqin et al., 2009; Kontos et al., 2005; Sener et al., 2010; Sharifi et al., 2009,).

Landfill sites should not be located on the aquifer areas.
Landfill sites should not degrade natural environmentally sensitive areas (EPA, 2006; Kontos et al., 2005).
Vegetation types related to from evaluation (Guiqin et al., 2009).
Landfill sites should not be located on prime agricultural land such as first and second classes (Nas et al., 2008; Sharifi et al., 2009; Yesilnacar and Cetin, 2005).
Landfill sites should be located on the areas that have low permeable soil (Moeinaddini et al., 2010).
It is preferred to locate landfill sites on impermeable clay (Yesilnacar and Cetin, 2005).

Landfill areas should be located at a significant distance away from settlements due to public concerns, such as aesthetics, odour (Tagaris et al., 2003), decrease in property value (Zeiss and Lefsrud, 1995), and health concerns, such as the contamination of freshwater aquifers through leaching (Nagar and Mirza, 2006).
Landfill sites should not be placed on a site close to historical or cultural sites (EPA, 2006; Nas et al., 2008; Moeinaddini et al., 2010).
Areas degraded by quarry activities or disused quarries should be considered as preferential within evaluation process (De Feo and De Gisi, 2010).

sec.p: Criteria can be classified as factors and constraints. A factor is a criterion that enhances the suitability of a specific alternative for the activity under consideration. A constraint limits the alternatives under consideration while it classifies the areas into two classes: unsuitable (value 0) or suitable (value 1). As there are many constraints according to the criteria selected in the following section, GIS-based constraint mapping was developed to eliminate unsuitable sites for each criterion. The list of factors considered for selecting the disposal sites and their indicated buffers are given in Table 2.

In this study, distance from waste generation centers criteria was calculated by the centre of gravity principle. As explained before, the study area includes several municipalities and due to the amount of waste generation, a single landfill site area was considered to be selected which would offer service to the whole region. The centre of gravity principle was used to determine the location of a single landfill site that would minimize waste collection costs. This strategy is helpful for those situations where geography and transportation costs are important. The main centre of gravity points correspond to the population number based on the TCC census data and the distance to the major urban areas of Northern Cyprus (Table 3).

sec.title: Pairwise comparisons
sec.p: Pairwise comparison matrices were formed by interviews conducted with various experts from different departments such as a civil engineer, environmental engineer, town planner, geology engineer, etc. These experts divided into two different groups and completed criteria weighting from environmental and economic points of view. The first group preferred to increase the environmental criteria set weights whereas the second group concentrated on the economic ones. The consistency ratios (CR) of the two weighting schemas were checked to verify the reliability of these experts’ choices. According to Saaty (1980) CR should have a value of less than 10%. In this study, the CR values were lower values than 10% which indicates the consistency of the pairwise comparison (Tables 4 and 5).

sec.title: Analysis and results
sec.p: Two suitability maps with two groups of weights were constructed using AHP values based on the attributes of each criteria layer. ArcGIS model builder was also used for testing the values and preparation of final suitability map. The model builder process has three main steps. In the first step, constraint map development was calculated with the raster calculator tool based on the exclusionary areas for each criteria layer. Each layer was recoded within the model process according to the layer’ zones, and all exclusionary areas were defined as ‘0’ while the rest of the zones were defined as ‘1’ (Figure 6).

In the second step, the weighted sum tool was used for 12 layers including their AHP criteria weights. Each layer’s weights were also summed based on layer attribute zones. Two final suitability maps were developed by overlaying (multiplying) the two raster images that were produced through the first and second steps. To compare the two groups of different weights-based suitability maps, four suitability classes were set by using the custom classification method. These groups were defined as areas with: high suitability (+0.30), medium suitability (0.30–0.20), low suitability (0.20–0.10) and very low suitability (0.10–0). The rest of the areas were masked using the constraint map and classified as ‘unsuitable’ (Figure 7(a) and (b)).

caption.p: (a) First group suitability map; (b) second group suitability map; (c) comparison first and second group suitability maps results.

sec.p: The first group suitability map has 11 052 (ha) with high suitability class. It also has 9642 (ha) and 2526 (ha) for medium and low classes, respectively. However in the case of the second group, high suitability areas decreased to 5982 (ha) whereas medium suitability increased to 13 636 (ha). In addition, areas with low suitability reached 3595 (ha) (Figure 7(c)).

From these results, possible potential sites were defined based on the area requirements defined in the study area. As was explained in the section above entitled ‘Study area’, approximately 190 000 m2 (19 ha) of area is required for locating a landfill site. Therefore, this particular amount of area was included in analysis within the highly suitable areas and marked on both suitability maps for LSS (Figure 8(a) and (b)).

caption.p: (a) Potential sites within the first group suitability map results; (b) potential sites within the second group suitability map results.

sec.p: The first suitability map shows seven potential sites for LSS in the high suitability zones and the second group has five alternatives. Four of these potential sites (Gungor, Degirmenlik, Kirklar and Cayonu) share common locations with high suitability areas. The remaining three potential sites have medium suitability in terms of the results of the second suitability map. This also shows that the environmental criteria set have a great impact on the study area and affects the output result.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study shows that the integration of GIS and AHP-based MCE represents an effective and efficient LSS process in Northern Cyprus. GIS enables the manipulation of spatial data by using various spatial operations. These operations help to construct spatial databases for use as criteria or factors. Furthermore, the AHP is a powerful tool for solving complicated problems that may have interactions among multiple objectives. Thus, the integration of GIS and AHP methods provides a mechanism to explore complicated problems and provide feedback for decision-makers.

In order to solve this complex LSS problem, 12 criteria were determined by reviewing international literature and assessing them in terms of the regional characteristics and data availability. These included economic criteria such as distance from waste generation centres, distance from roads, slope, environmental criteria such as distance from surface waters, distance from groundwater areas, distance from environmentally sensitive areas, vegetation types, soil productivity, soil permeability and physical criteria such as distance from settlements, distance from cultural sites, distance from stone quarries. In particular, the centre of gravity principle was used for developing distance from waste generation centres. These criteria were effective for dealing with the selection of one single landfill site for the whole study region where the land area is limited and waste collection costs will be minimized.

In many LSS studies, the evaluation process is generally concentrated on single urban areas (Chang et al., 2008) or municipalities (Al-Jarrah and Abu-Qdais, 2006; Sumathi et al., 2008) and even though they have more than one city or settlement within the study area, the evaluation process does not consider the potential amount of waste based on spatial distribution. From the planning perspective, it is important to also take into consideration the spatial distribution of the amount of waste. Additionally, many LSS studies aim to find proper locations without damaging the physical or natural environment within selected administrative boundaries. This may create one landfill site for each municipality in many regions which is a waste of land. Therefore, the present study tried to set additional criteria to develop the centre of gravity principle for optimization of land usage within the LSS process.

Additionally, two groups of weights were used by technical experts in this study. Therefore, two different suitability maps were produced at the final stage. The first group suitability map identified 11 052 (ha) in the high suitability class, whereas the high suitability areas decreased to 5982 (ha) in the results of the second group. Moreover, the location of seven potential sites decreased to four in the second suitability map. However, potential sites such as Gungor, Degirmenlik, Kirklar and Cayonu had similarities with higher suitability values and were effectively the same locations according to both first and second suitability map results. Thus, even though different weights were used for economic and environmental criteria sets, common potential sites were detected within the study area.

The selected criteria list has not been finalized for Northern Cyprus but it is useful in many regions where the land is limited. Furthermore, this list may be increased according to the availability of data. Additional criteria such as land ownership, electricity supply, etc. should be considered, and added for the final evaluation among the potential sites given above. It must be noted that the presented approach is only for supporting the decision-makers in selection of criteria sets for Northern Cyprus but it also offers ideas about potential sites for LSS for use in further research studies.
